shichuanwuhan@... wrote:
Re: [archive-crawler] What on earth is the different between seeds and 
surts-source-file?
> I don't understand even though I have read the user manual many many times.

The 'seeds' are the starting URIs for the crawl. The crawler will 
actually attempt to visit the exact URIs in the seeds file. Then, 
depending on what outlinks are discovered, and what are ruled as 
in-scope, the crawler may visit other URIs as well.

The term 'seeds' is widely used for this meaning in other writing about 
web crawling, as well.

The term 'SURT', as a special URI syntax useful for describing where a 
crawler should go, is more specific to Heritrix. (Other crawlers have 
similar ideas under other names.) The meaning of 'SURT' and 
'SURT-prefix' is covered in the manual.

If you are using scope rules based on SURT prefixes, your scope may load 
acceptable SURTs from a file. The lines in this file are read as either 
literal SURT-prefixes, or URIs that are converted into 'implied 
SURT-prefixes'. Nothing in this file forces the crawler to try visiting 
a URI. Rather, it just makes visiting some URIs allowable, *if* those 
URIs are discovered by some other path.

If starting from the default configuration bundled with the crawler, 
it's rare to need to use the 'surts-source-file'. First, because that 
configuration is already set to treat every seed as also implying a 
matching SURT-prefix, to allow the crawl to travel to natural/intuitive 
'extensions' of the seed. And second, because if you just need to add a 
few more SURT-prefixes, you can do so using the shortcut syntax of extra 
lines in the seeds file.

For example, this seeds file:

===seeds.txt===
http://example.com/staff/~examplesen
+http://(com,example,
===============

...is equivalent to the pair of both seeds file and surts-file:

===seeds.txt===
http://example.com/staff/~examplesen
===============

===surts.txt===
+http://(com,example,
===============

In both cases, the crawler is only told to explicitly visit the exact 
URI 'http://example.com/staff/~examplesen'. However, *if* it discovers 
outlink URIs anywhere in the 'example.com' domain, it will follow those 
links.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
